awd_titl_txt: Developing Ethical Guidelines and Best Practices for the Use of Volunteered Geographic Information and Remotely Sensed Imagery in Crisis Situations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop ethical principles and guidelines, as well as draft best practices for the use of remote sensing and volunteered geographic information (VGI) in crisis situations. Since there are no existing guidelines or best practices to guide such research, the results of the project will be transformative for researchers and collaborators in the field. Moreover, it will have a ripple effect through development of educational materials to prepare future researchers to understand and give priority to their responsibilities when conducting collaborative research with non-scientists. Remote sensing and VGI generate geolocated data used not just by scientists, but also by practitioners with little scientific training seeking to intervene in crisis situations, which often unfold in remote and dangerous locations inhabited by vulnerable populations and may involve human rights abuses, humanitarian and disaster responses, and threats to cultural heritage during conflict.  Hence, the project will not only promote the ethical and rigorous use of these techniques for researchers, it will also guide the work of stakeholders outside academia, a crucial step to reducing risks to populations. Given the global settings in which crises emerge, this project reaches beyond traditional scholarly audiences to disseminate research findings and approaches. It will include non-scientist users and the voices of under-represented groups, such as people in the developing world and women, in order to diversify discussions on the best ways to protect on-the-ground researchers, the volunteers of information, and those threatened by the misuse or careless distribution of geolocated information. 

Geographers are well-positioned to develop and apply remote sensing and VGI approaches to socially important issues. Nevertheless, methodological lapses may impede further progress. Some methodological issues addressed by this project include: data provenance; quality control in data collection and analysis; representativeness of the collected data; and potential data gaps due to factors such as gender and access to technology. These are core matters for how a professional discipline establishes standards for assessing the rigor and accuracy of its methods and instrumentation, and how it applies those methods in an ethically acceptable manner. While such matters fall into the domain of the profession, they cannot be understood fully in the present day social context without dialogue with non-scientist users. Two key research questions explored by this study include:

1. What standards are needed for the collection, analysis, use and dissemination of geolocated data during crisis situations? Operating without standards endangers the safety and security of people on the ground and complicates efforts to identify appropriate policy and interventions to protect and assist populations. 
2. What are the best means for engaging a diverse set of geographers and users in developing and disseminating those standards - ethical principles and guidelines and best practices - so they are accepted and implemented in studies that use geolocated data in crisis situations?

These and other questions will be addressed through a series of invitational workshops and solicitations of feedback from stakeholder communities. Participants will be drawn from the international academic, humanitarian, cultural heritage, crisis mapping, disaster, and human rights communities.

por.por_cntn:
In crisis situations, the value of using location-based data and other geospatial information can be immense, in monitoring the situation, developing targeted responses, locating populations at particular risk, and in contributing to accountability in the aftermath. As a result, organizations are increasingly turning to new technologies such as imagery collected using satellites and unmanned aerial vehicles, as well as volunteered geographic information (VGI), a form of user-generated location-based information. The use of such data in a crisis-response context, however, may give rise to serious ethical issues, as it may pose risks to the safety of vulnerable individuals, groups, and sites when data are intentionally or unintentionally misused. This project sought to provide crisis response practitioners with the tools necessary to make use of the capabilities that are enabled by location-based data in a responsible, ethical, and methodologically rigorous manner. The guiding hypothesis is that, through the development of contextually appropriate ethical principles, guidelines, and best practices, the use of such data could more effectively and responsibly employed in domains such as human rights documentation, humanitarian and disaster response, and cultural heritage in conflict.

To accomplish these goals, a series of three 2-day invitational workshops were held at AAAS with the goal of better understanding the situations to which remote sensing and VGI have been and could be successfully and ethically applied, and to identify best practices for data collection, security, analysis, use, and dissemination. The three workshops built upon each other, allowing ethical and practical issues to be explored in depth, commonalities across situations and methods to be identified, and the underlying ethical principles to be described and debated. Following the workshops, a document was drafted outlining five overarching principles for the use of remote sensing and VGI in crisis situations. Each of these principles is associated with specific guidelines which provide more detailed and specific direction to practitioners for implementing the principle in the field. These principles and guidelines were written to be agnostic with regard to any particular technological platform, and instead focus on the implications of the new capabilities that these technologies continue to enable.

The principles and guidelines also formed the basis for the development of a series of case studies and decision trees that, which taken together provide a clear guide for applying the principles and guidelines in a real-world crisis response context. All of these outputs (principles, guidelines, case studies, and decision trees) were subsequently published on the AAAS website. To formally introduce the principles, guidelines, case studies, and decision trees, a public launch event was held at AAAS on March 20, 2019 in which a series of speakers addressed how the principles and guidelines apply in diverse practical contexts, the particular risks that they would help bring to light, and ethical responses to those challenges. This was followed in the afternoon by an invitation-only “train the trainers” workshop in which selected individuals from fields related to crisis-response used the decision trees by applying them to a series of hypothetical scenarios. Finally, in mid-June 2019 AAAS hosted a webinar to reach an international audience for these tools as well as other domestic researchers and field workers beyond those who were able to attend the launch event and training workshop in person. All project materials are publicly available on the project website and the webinar is also archived online.
